headline: Staking a Position
summary: See where House races fall on a grid that breaks down the representative's electoral success and the district's political tilt.

headline: Along for the Ride
summary: Some Accuride bondholders gained from the upswing during the company's bankruptcy. See Accuride bond prices and important dates.

headline: Yukos Probe
summary: Defense lawyers for jailed Russian oil tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky are turning their legal guns on one of their client's former allies: auditor PriceWaterhouseCoopers. Take a look at some key days looking into the Yukos probe.

headline: CORRECTION
summary: The Center for Constitutional Rights is suing the Obama administration to enjoin Predator drone attacks against U.S. citizens overseas. The center was misidentified in the Sept. 2 editorial "The Lawfare Wars."

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Sept. 7

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Tuesday, Sept. 7, 2010

headline: U.S. Open Photos: Day 9
summary: Russian Mikhail Youzhny beat Tommy Robredo Tuesday slowing Spain's march through the U.S. Open bracket.

headline: Szechuan in Midtown
summary: Szechuan Gourmet is for iron-stomached diners who crave the bold flavors of Southwest China, unafraid of that cuisine's distinct, potent spice.

headline: Redesigning Daytime
summary: Nate Berkus made a name for himself re-decorating rooms on "The Oprah Winfrey Show." On September 13 he gets his own daytime talk show that mixes design with life advice. A look at some of the rooms on which Mr. Berkus has made his mark.

headline: Maruti to Build New Plant
summary: Maruti Suzuki India will invest ¥35 billion to build a new car plant in Manesar in the northern state of Haryana, the chairman of its parent Suzuki Motor said.

headline: National Bank of Greece to Raise $3.6 Billion in Capital
summary: National Bank of Greece will proceed with a plan to raise $3.6 billion in capital that its board will be called to approve on Friday.

headline: Gold Hits a New Peak
summary: The Dow industrials fell 107.24 points, or 1%, to 10340.69, moving back into the red for the year, as banking worries from Europe put investors on the defensive.

headline: Cisco Settles Charges
summary: The Justice Department said Cisco and Westcon Group North America agreed to pay $48 million to settle charges that the companies made misrepresentations during contract negotiations with the federal government.

headline: SEC Looking at 'Quote Stuffing'
summary: SEC Chairman Mary Schapiro said the agency is looking at a practice others have called "quote stuffing" to assess whether it violates "existing rules against fraudulent or other improper behavior."

headline: For Austerity Action, a Reaction
summary: Strikes and other protest actions that now have spread from Greece to Europe's big economies cast a cloud over EU reforms and economic recovery.

headline: Headwaters Slides 7.2%; Casey's Gets Bump on Bid
summary: Small-capitalization stocks sank Tuesday as renewed concerns over the global financial system switched off investors' willingness to wade into riskier stocks.

headline: BofA Falls but Oracle Moves Up
summary: Financial stocks including American Express, J.P. Morgan Chase and Bank of America led U.S. stocks lower as the market cooled from last week's rally.

headline: Eldorado Withdraws Bid
summary: Eldorado Gold withdrew its competing bid for Andean Resources, saying it wouldn't top Goldcorp's offer of $3.48 billion.

headline: Chicago Mayor Daley Ends His Run
summary: Richard M. Daley, the second-longest serving mayor in Chicago history and the scion of one of the country's great political dynasties, announced Tuesday he would not seek a seventh term in 2011.

headline: Homeland Security Sued Over Search Policies
summary: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security has been sued over its policies that allegedly authorize the search and seizure of laptops, cellphones and other electronic devices without a reasonable suspicion of wrongdoing, the ACLU said.

headline: Treasurys Rally After Auction
summary: The U.S. sold three-year Treasury notes for the lowest yield on record, and Treasurys rallied as renewed concerns about the euro zone spurred demand for low-risk debt.

headline: Judge Refuses to Stay Stem-Cell Ruling
summary: A federal judge refused to stay his ruling that blocked the federal government from funding human embryonic stem-cell research.

headline: Purdue Pharma to Settle Oxycontin Claims
summary: Purdue Pharma agreed to pay $16 million to settle a lawsuit by purchasers of Oxycontin over how it obtained patents on the painkiller in the 1990s.

headline: Hedge Funds Cave In to Rallying Bond Market
summary: Hedge funds and other speculative investors turned bullish on the benchmark 10-year Treasury notes for the first time in 20 months, as many participants caved in to a rallying bond market.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Summer Stock
summary: For peace of mind then, if not profit, taking the summer off might have made sense.

headline: Boeing Unit Sees Revenue Growing
summary: Revenue at Boeing's satellite systems unit should grow slightly in coming years, helped by commercial demand, the unit's chief executive said.

headline: Photos of the Day: Sept. 7
summary: In Tuesday's pictures, a woman takes a salt bath in Russia, Afghans tread on the U.S. flag, Greece's Athena Nike temple gets back up and running and more.

headline: BarCap Promotes Lieutenants from Lehman Deal
summary: Jerry del Missier and Rich Ricci were key figures in BarCap's bid for Lehman. Two years on, the duo have been named co-chiefs of Barclays's investment-banking arm that so transformed by that deal.

headline: Boeing to Revamp Military Aircraft Unit
summary: Boeing said Tuesday it will restructure its military aircraft business, collapsing six divisions into four, which will lead to the loss of over 400 jobs.

headline: Bank Stocks Lead Market Skid
summary: Financial stocks were among the biggest decliners, mimicking moves in Europe amid fresh concerns about the continent's banking system.

headline: Dell, Home Depot Lead Flood of Debt
summary: A deluge of new investment-grade bonds flooded the market, with Dell, Home Depot and other top-rated companies issuing more than $9 billion in debt.

headline: Connaught Taps Administrator
summary: U.K. support-services firm Connaught named KPMG as administrators for the company and its subsidiary, Connaught Partnerships.

headline: Powerful Position
summary: None

headline: HSBC's New Chairman Must Come From Outside
summary: Hiring Stephen Green as Minister for Trade and Investment is undoubtedly a coup for U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron. But his departure from HSBC, six months earlier than envisaged, is also an opportunity for the bank.

headline: Gold Climbs Past $1,261
summary: Gold futures hit their highest point in more than two months as fears about European banks stoked safe-harbor buying.

headline: Oil Prices Fall on Recovery Concerns
summary: Crude futures settled lower on concerns about the health of the global economy, even as a refinery explosion in Mexico pushed oil products higher.

headline: Morgan Stanley Cuts Yield Call
summary: Morgan Stanley revised down its forecast for the 10-year Treasury note's yield to 3% for the end of the year, from 3.5% projected last month.

headline: Royal Mail Pension Plan Narrows Deficit
summary: A sophisticated derivatives strategy has helped the pension fund for the U.K.'s Royal Mail to make a 29% return on its money last year, reducing the company's deficit and potentially helping along its possible privatization.

headline: Big on Bureks
summary: Get away from the chain restaurants around Times Square with Djerdan, a taste of home for those from the former Yugoslavia.

headline: Floods Hit Southeast Australia
summary: Hundreds of homes have been inundated in Australia's southeastern state of Victoria amid strong winds and heavy rains that caused the worst flooding in the state in more than a decade.

headline: TPV Capitalizes on Rising Consumer Demand
summary: TPV Chairman Jason Hsuan is upbeat about industry growth prospects because of rising outsourcing orders from TV makers and the uptake of new products such as three-dimensional TVs and LED backlit TVs.

headline: Enterprise Products, Enterprise GP Strike Deal
summary: Oil-and-gas pipeline companies Enterprise Products Partners and Enterprise GP announced a unit-based merger that values Enterprise GP at about $8 billion.

headline: Bank Fears Drag Down European Markets
summary: None

headline: Dean Foods CEO Expects Challenges for Milk Market
summary: The head of Dean Foods Co. said Tuesday that margins at the largest U.S. milk producer remain under pressure from discounting retailers, though the company expects to meet cost-cutting targets ahead of schedule.

headline: A Write-In Senator?
summary: Republican operatives are openly fretting that Ms. Murkowski will be tempted to use what is likely a $1.5 million warchest to keep her seat.

headline: Connecticut Pressures Craigslist on Prostitution Ads
summary: Connecticut's attorney general wants confirmation that Craigslist has closed its adult-services section, used for prostitution ads. Currently that part of the site says "censored."

headline: Infosys Sees No Softening in Demand
summary: Infosys is confident of achieving the high end of its revenue-growth forecast for the current quarter as the software exporter sees sustained momentum in the volume of technology outsourcing work.

headline: London Copes With Transit Disruptions
summary: Strikes in London's transport systems could become the first in a series of strikes affecting millions of commuters ahead of government cuts later in the fall.

headline: Small-Business Tax Cuts Fuel Debate
summary: Republicans and Democrats debated the potential impact of an Obama administration proposal to provide tax cuts to small businesses, with critics saying it wouldn't be sufficient to turn around the struggling economy.

headline: Report: Bush Could Lose His Heisman
summary: 2005 Heisman Trophy winner Reggie Bush could be stripped of the award by the end of the month.

headline: Bank Shares Fall in Europe
summary: Bank shares led European markets lower after a Wall Street Journal article on EU stress tests raised fears about lenders' exposure to sovereign debt.

headline: Advice for Foreign Home Buyers
summary: It's a very straightforward process if you pay all-cash. If you need a mortgage, the process will be challenging.

headline: Can't Keep Investment Bankers Down
summary: Several recent moves raise the intriguing possibility that investment bankers are heading for a clean sweep of running the biggest banks in the U.K. and Europe.

headline: NYSE to Expand Carbon Trading
summary: plans to expand its carbon-trading business from Europe to the U.S. and Asia through a joint venture that sets up a three-way battle among exchanges to expand a once-promising market.

headline: Ocado Shares Slide After First Sales Report
summary: Online grocer Ocado reported subdued third-quarter sales that disappointed investors and further knocked its share price.

headline: Withdrawals Drop at Afghan Bank
summary: Withdrawals from beleaguered Kabul Bank dropped sharply, a day after the country's central banker said the bank would get a bailout if it needed one.

headline: Mizuho Sees Acquisitions as Route to Asia Expansion
summary: Mizuho Financial wants to expand in fast-growing Asia by investing in local financial institutions and building up its existing operations there, according to a senior executive at the bank.

headline: Fiery French Protests
summary: French unions expect two million protesters to demonstrate against the government's pension-overhaul plan on Tuesday, confronting head-on the central plank of President Nicolas Sarkozy's fiscal changes.

headline: Asian Markets Finish Mixed
summary: Asian stocks ended mixed as exporters held down Japanese shares  on yen worries while steelmakers climbed on expectations of higher Chinese prices. The Nikkei fell 0.8%.

headline: BOJ Holds Policy Steady
summary: The Bank of Japan kept its super-loose monetary policy unchanged Tuesday but expressed stronger concern about the yen's surge to 15-year highs.

headline: Petronas Chemicals Plans Malaysian IPO
summary: The unit of Malaysian state-owned oil corporation Petroliam Nasional may raise as much as $3.53 billion in its initial share sale, in what would be among Southeast Asia's biggest offerings ever.

headline: Woods Makes U.S. Ryder Cup Team
summary: Tiger Woods will make his sixth Ryder Cup team, but the first for which he didn't qualify automatically.

headline: Japanese Yields Fall
summary: Japanese government bond yields dropped as the country's central bank signaled openness to further monetary easing and as the yen remained strong, sustaining demand for safe-haven assets.

headline: Australia Leaves Rates on Hold
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia left its cash rate target unchanged at 4.5% for a fourth month in a row.

headline: Trump Place Conversion
summary: The owner of this Trump Place condo on the Upper West Side combined two units to create an art-filled 2,500-square-foot home.

headline: Kia Motors Names New Vice Chairman
summary: Kia Motors said President Lee Hyoung-keun has been promoted to succeed former vice chairman Chung Sung-eun who resigned after taking responsibility for a recall.

headline: ResCare Agrees to Onex's Bid
summary: ResCare agreed to an increased buyout offer from investment firm Onex that values the provider of home care to the elderly at about $384 million.

headline: British Airways in Codesharing Pact With Kingfisher
summary: British Airways said it has entered into a codesharing agreement with Kingfisher Airlines., under which both carriers will use each other's flight network as part of their expansion.

headline: U.S. Official: China Faces Backlash
summary: Robert Hormats, a top U.S. State Department official warned that China risks a backlash from Congress unless it becomes more responsive to international concerns about its currency value and trade practices.

headline: SpiceJet to Start Overseas Flights
summary: SpiceJet said it will start flights to two overseas destinations in October, making it the first Indian budget carrier to fly internationally.

headline: Strike Slows London Commute
summary: Strikes in London's transport systems, which started late on Sunday and are due to continue until Tuesday evening, could become the first in a series of strikes affecting millions of commuters ahead of government cuts later in the fall.

headline: Shinhan Chairman Under Investigation
summary: South Korea's financial watchdog is investigating whether Mr. Ra held bank accounts that weren't opened in his name, deepening management woes for the firm and damaging its reputation.

headline: Wipro Sees "Moderate Impact" from U.S. Visa Fee Hike
summary: Wipro expects the higher U.S. visa costs to have a "moderate impact" on its operating margins in the current fiscal year, even as the software exporter looks to pass the increased cost on to clients.

headline: India May Reap Bumper Winter Crop
summary: India may reap a bumper winter-sown crop including wheat and oilseeds this crop year as heavy monsoon rains have raised water reservoir levels beyond the 10-year average and increased soil moisture.

headline: RBI: Indian Banks Unlikely Affected by New Rules
summary: Indian banks are unlikely to be significantly affected by proposed new global banking rules which may require lenders to have more capital and liquidity, Reserve Bank of India Governor Duvvuri Subbarao said.

headline: China Hints at Tighter Regulation on Gas Sector
summary: The fledgling city gas sector has been lightly regulated until recently, but that could change as more consumers switch from burning coal and oil to less-polluting natural gas.

headline: U.K. May Reopen Probe into Hacking
summary: A four-year-old tabloid scandal has resurfaced to dog the U.K. Prime Minister's chief spokesman, as police said they may reopen their probe into alleged use of dubious reporting tactics by the News of the World newspaper when he was its editor.

headline: Protests in Kashmir
summary: Tensions in Kashmir have flared up yet again after four more protesters were killed in a clash with police on Monday. Some snapshots.

headline: Expect More for Less from New Insurance Plans
summary: India's much-debated unit-linked insurance plans now have lower charges and longer lock-ins, says Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer.

headline: 'Shenzhen Speed': Thirty Years Later
summary: This week, Shenzhen, a one-time fishing village that turned into a boomtown with one of the highest per-capita income levels in mainland China, is celebrating the 30th anniversary of its founding as a special economic zone.

headline: Afghans Move to Bail Out Kabul Bank
summary: Afghanistan's government inched closer to bailing out the country's largest bank, setting aside hundreds of millions of dollars that could be used to keep Kabul Bank solvent, officials said.

headline: To Sign Revis, Jets Grab a...Jet
summary: The New York Jets ditched their combat stance with holdout Darrelle Revis, jumped on a bird and lured the star cornerback home.

headline: The Euro Zone's Next Big Headache
summary: The European Central Bank must balance the growth of Germany against the contraction of Greece while shackled by a one-size-fits-all interest rate.

headline: Unilever Invests in Algae
summary: As food and consumer-goods companies face problems obtaining the key ingredient palm oil without damaging the environment, Unilever is betting on a promising low-life alternative: algae.

headline: Hyundai Bidding War Looms
summary: The sale of Hyundai Engineering will pit two former sister companies against each other. A deal could fetch $3 billion for the construction firm's creditors.

headline: Pinched Workers Try Day Labor
summary: The face of day labor appears to be changing, with more women, non-Latinos and former white-collar workers resorting to manual labor.

headline: Obama Unveils Infrastructure Plan
summary: Obama unveiled a new $50 billion proposal to improve the nation's highways, airports and railways – the latest attempt by the administration to jump-start the sputtering economy.

headline: Challenges Cloud German Reactor Plan
summary: Germany's government and energy utilities ended months of wrangling and agreed to extend the life of the country's nuclear-power plants, but popular resistance and possible legal challenges cloud the fate of the deal.

headline: Toshiba Plans to Release Tablet
summary: Toshiba said that it will release by year-end a tablet computer that runs on Google's Android operating system as the company aims to compete with Apple's iPad.

headline: Prosecutors Question Rice's Luring-Bill Push
summary: As a candidate for attorney general, Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice has pledged to back a state law to make it a felony to lure a child on the Internet. But a review of existing laws suggests that such a law has been on the books since 2008.

headline: William Easterly: The Hazards of Doing Good
summary: From Live Aid in the mid-1980s to today, Western attempts to help famine-plagued Ethiopia have had little effect. Peter Gill explains why in "Famine and Foreigners."

headline: Study Examines Sugar as Pain Reliever for Tots
summary: In The Research Report, Jeremy Singer-Vine summarizes new medical findings on infant pain; circadian rhythms; lung cancer; cognitive exercise; migraine; low-carbohydrate diets; esophageal cancer and heart health.

headline: U.S. Open: Day Eight Photos
summary: Third-seeded Novak Djokovic routed No. 19-seeded American Mardy Fish and Dominika Cibulkova upset No. 11 Svetlana Kuznetsova 7-5, 7-6 (4) to make the quarterfinals.

headline: In Short Supply: Pinball Wizards Who Can Fix Old Machines
summary: Old pinball machines were not built to last, and finding a repairman can be close to impossible.

headline: Global-Bank Deal Targets Reserves
summary: Global banking regulators appear poised to demand larger reserves, which they believe will prevent a future financial crisis, and reserves of higher quality, under so-called Basel 3.

headline: OPEN RACKET: The Scene in Flushing
summary: A 34-year-old spider monkey named Grandpa to predict U.S. Open results. Novak Djokovic keeps his postmatch comments PG. Leander Paes plans his posttennis career. A U.S. Open app comes up short. And Carnegie Deli's pastrami sandwich makes the food Final Four.

headline: Yanks Lose to Orioles, 4-3
summary: A home run by Alex Rodriguez, a double by slumping Derek Jeter and an encouraging outing by A.J. Burnett failed to produce a win against the Orioles.

headline: Colleges Respond to ObamaCare
summary: Your editorial "Big Foot on Campus; Why colleges want a waiver from ObamaCare" (Aug. 26) misses the mark.i Colleges are not seeking a "waiver" from the law. We want to ensure that institutions have the ability to offer students high-quality plans that comply with the law.

headline: Hunt for New Candidates Leads to CEOs
summary: A hunger for fresh faces, especially among Republicans, has propelled a bumper crop of novice politicians into the electoral fray. Prominent among the rookies are several CEO candidates running on their business resumes.

headline: UPS Crash Puts Focus on Cockpit Smoke
summary: The investigation into the United Parcel Service Inc. cargo plane that crashed while attempting to return to Dubai last week, killing both pilots, has revived safety concerns about preventing and responding to cockpit smoke.

headline: Lehman Case in U.K. Raises Questions Over Client Funds
summary: Treatment of clients' funds after bank's collapse leads to High Court case, and a possible revision of regulations.

headline: Will Brussels Boycott De Gucht?
summary: The European trade commissioner explains why the 'average' Jew is so irrational.

headline: Helping a Loved One Fight Depression
summary: What can you do when your depressed loved one won't get treatment -- or denies he or she even has a problem?

headline: Larger Bounties Spur Surge in Fraud Tips
summary: New awards for informants who help the SEC uncover fraud are already prompting a surge in tips.

headline: Filmmaker Shines Spotlight on School Lunches
summary: Avis and Bruce Richards, president of Marathon Asset Management, have created a documentary short called "Lunch," which examines what children are eating at school and advocates for healthier meals in schools.

headline: The Obama Economy
summary: How trillions in fiscal and monetary stimulus produced a 1.6% recovery.

headline: TIAA, Omnicom In Lease Talks
summary: A huge retirement system that just bought a soon-to-be empty East Side office tower is in preliminary talks with ad giant Omnicom Group Inc. about leasing a large chunk of space.

headline: Jamie Whyte: The Busybody Society
summary: Beggars can not be choosers, but why must British citizens be beggars?

headline: Insurers Pin Rate Hikes on Health Law
summary: Insurers plan to raise premiums on some Americans as a result of the health overhaul as soon as next month, complicating Democrats' efforts to trumpet their signature achievement ahead of elections.

headline: I Can Afford My Home With the Right Loan
summary: Your editorial "The Housing Mirage" (Aug. 25) reflects a common misconception held by many outside the "housing meltdown ground zero" regions. My problem is not that I can't afford my home, but that I can't afford my existing 15-year mortgage. I need a 30-year, but I'm unable to refinance because of its decline in value.

headline: Bay's Season May Have Come to an End
summary: The Mets transferred left fielder Jason Bay from the 15-day disabled list to the 60-day DL, making it unlikely that he would play again this season. Also, two Giants rookies got haircuts, and the Liberty is one loss away from elimination.

headline: Airgas Bid Raised By Suitor
summary: Air Products & Chemicals raised its cash offer for smaller rival Airgas to $65.50 a share, or $5.48 billion, in its hostile takeover bid.

headline: GM Will Face Questions About Opel
summary: As GM gears up to pitch its IPO to investors this fall, one of the tougher tasks it faces is making the case that its Opel operations in Europe can be fixed.

headline: Mirae Asset's Im Forecasts Growth of Asia's Middle Class
summary: Sungho Im, head of global investment at Mirae Asset Global Investment, tells The Wall Street Journal that Asia's growing middle class will present long-term investment opportunities.

headline: Lessons of Lehman's Flighty Funding
summary: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Committee released emails that show Lehman's overuse of short-term debt was a problem well before its collapse. The U.S. financial-overhaul efforts don't do enough to limit banks' use of the repo market.

headline: Jets Embrace Revis on His Return
summary: After a lengthy holdout, cornerback Darrelle Revis agrees to a four-year, $46 million contract and reports to camp.

headline: States Test Out New Math
summary: As the school year begins, changes to education laws are kicking in across the U.S. as part of Obama's push to overhaul K-12 public schools.

headline: ABC News to Keep Approach
summary: Disney's ABC News unit is likely to continue a shift to a leaner, lower-cost approach to news gathering as it seeks a successor to longtime head David Westin.

headline: Adviser Shift Is Expected to Boost ETF Sales
summary: Exchange-traded funds have been embraced by fee-based financial advisers, something that will help fuel their growing popularity.

headline: Products Act as a Screen Against Pollen
summary: There is a growing category of natural therapies called pollen blockers that work by stopping allergens from getting into your nose and lungs.

headline: Japan's Race to Somewhere
summary: The Kan vs. Ozawa contest is good for political transparency.

headline: Euro, Sterling Weaken
summary: The euro gave up early gains as optimism over last week's better-than-expected U.S. nonfarm payrolls faded and investors eyed a packed calendar of central-bank meetings.

headline: Probe Finds New Meters Accurate
summary: An investigation spurred by a surge in energy-bill complaints found new smart meters installed in Northern California are accurately measuring energy use.

headline: An Exercise Class With an Element of Joy
summary: Yoga and other group exercise activities sometimes feel like just another form of competition. But exercise can co-exist with an element of joy. And it's happening in the basement of an old luggage factory in Park Slope

headline: 'Japan Premium'
summary: For decades, foreign, high-end retailers got away with charging a "Japan premium": a hefty mark-up on imported items in the world's single biggest market for luxury goods.

headline: Indian Road Hits Unexpected Bump
summary: India long has had trouble acquiring land to build the infrastructure essential for rapid economic growth. Now its own ruling party is increasingly opposing developments.

headline: For Developers, a Time of Opportunity
summary: The economic downturn has lead civic groups and community boards to rethink their longtime policies of limiting retailers.

headline: From Russia, With Budget Deficits
summary: Why eradicate bad behavior when you can tax it?

headline: Big Sister to 13,000 Cabbies
summary: Bhairavi Desai appears an unlikely leader of a large, predominantly male, labor organization, but she is a skilled and relentless advocate for the New York Taxi Workers Alliance's 13,000 members.

headline: Giulio Meotti: Italia, R.I.P.
summary: By 2050, 60% percent of Italians will have no brothers, no sisters, no cousins, no aunts, no uncles.

headline: When Rendering Doesn't Match Reality
summary: The new condo-hotel on West 45th Street, called Cassa NY, which is getting its final touches, won't be what the building's star architect, Enrique Norten of Ten Arquitectos, initially had in mind.

headline: The Good News About Rising Mortgage Rates
summary: Rising mortgage rates may seem like the last thing the economy needs right now. Then again, they may prove a tonic.

headline: Slowing of Some Trades Is Urged
summary: Sen. Schumer urged federal securities regulators to explore ways to slow some high-speed trading at times of market stress and to investigate strategies that have raised stock-manipulation concerns.

headline: Apple Music: The Good, the Bad, the OK
summary: Apple is attempting to boost its digital-music arsenal by bringing social networking to iTunes and by redesigning three iPods. The results are mixed, writes Katherine Boehret.

headline: Climbing Treasury Yields to Help Auctions
summary: The Treasury market is in the middle of a price correction spurred by encouraging economic data, which bodes well for this week's auctions of $67 billion in notes and bonds.

headline: For Agassi, Discussion Is Open Book
summary: No topic was off limits for tennis star Andre Agassi at Thursday evening's "A Special Evening with Andre Agassi" at The Town Hall.

headline: Theodore Dalrymple: Politics and the Cult of Sentimentality
summary: Wilde said that sentimentality is the desire to have the luxury of emotion without paying for it.

headline: Japanese Political Battle Jolts Bonds
summary: The risk of a new prime minister who strongly favors higher fiscal spending continues to send yields in Japan's jittery government bond market sharply higher.

headline: Samsung Flags Record Investments
summary: Samsung is considering investing a record $25.55 billion next year to bolster its existing operations and expand into new businesses.
